content.webTitle: Ebola virus 'no threat' to Commonwealth Games athletes' village

fields.headline: Ebola virus 'no threat' to Commonwealth Games athletes' village
fields.bodyText: The organisers of the Commonwealth Games said on Friday that there was no threat to the athletes' village from the Ebola virus, after it emerged that a competitor from Sierra Leone had been tested in Glasgow for the deadly infection. "There is no Ebola in the athletes' village," Glasgow 2014 spokeswoman Jackie Brock-Doyle said. "There is no Ebola in Scotland." Moses Sesay, a cyclist in the Sierra Leonean squad, had been tested for Ebola among a number of other viruses after falling ill last week, the organisation said, but the results had been negative and he had competed as expected in Thursday's individual time trial event. The west African country is one of a number currently affected by the most deadly outbreak of the disease to date, which the director of the World Health Organisation said on Friday was "moving faster than efforts to control it". There was some confusion about a second athlete from the country, after Sierra Leone's chef de mission at the Games told the Daily Telegraph that another cyclist, Mohamed Tholley, had failed to compete in the same event and had possibly absconded. "The situation is very serious at home, and it is possible this is why he does not want to return," the paper quoted Unisa Deen Kargbo as saying. But Brock-Doyle later said the organisers were not alarmed. "We have now contacted the chef de mission and asked if they are concerned about the welfare of this athlete, has he gone missing, and whether they would like us to help, and they have said they are not concerned about the welfare or whereabouts of this athlete."
